content.topic: Is Hourly Pricing Dead? The Great Tattoo Pricing Debate
content.topicDescription: Three artists with very different pricing models debate the best approach. Hourly vs flat rate vs project-based. Who's right?
talkingPoints: What's your current pricing model and why?
When did you switch from hourly to your current model?
How do clients react to your pricing — any pushback?
What's the biggest mistake you see other artists make with pricing?
If a new artist asked you how to price their first year, what would you say?
Lightning round: name your price for these 3 hypothetical pieces
content.presenterNotes: Host moderates — don't let one voice dominate. After each question, go around the table: panelist 1 answers, then 2, then 3. Encourage friendly disagreement. The 'lightning round' at the end is the most shareable moment — keep it fast and fun. Display each panelist's headshot with lower-third when they're speaking.

panelists.name: Marcus Rodriguez
panelists.title: Traditional & Neo-Traditional — Project-Based Pricing
panelists.bio: Marcus runs a 3-chair shop in Austin and exclusively uses project-based pricing. He quotes every piece individually based on design complexity, placement, and size.
panelists.perspective: Hourly punishes fast artists. I quote the value, not the time.

panelists.name: Sarah Chen
panelists.title: Fine Line & Watercolor — Hourly Rate
panelists.bio: Sarah charges $250/hr from her private studio in Portland. She's been hourly for 8 years and has no plans to change. Her waitlist is 4 months.
panelists.perspective: Hourly is transparent and fair. Clients know exactly what they're paying for.

panelists.name: Devon Jackson
panelists.title: Black & Grey Realism — Day Rate
panelists.bio: Devon switched to a flat day rate of $1,500 two years ago. He only takes full-day sessions. His argument: it eliminates scope creep and lets him focus on the art.
panelists.perspective: Day rate changed my life. No more nickel-and-diming. One price, one day, one piece.
